>>So we've talked about water quality issues
and things in the water that can be of concern.

6.text:
And so this leads to the next step, which
would be: how do we treat the water to make

10.text:
that water safe to drink? And as we begin
to move into that discussion, maybe a good

14.text:
question to think about is: where is the safest
water on earth? When you think about naturally

20.text:
occurring water on earth, where do you think
about as as the safest water? And different

26.text:
answers come to mind. You might think about
groundwater, and that would be a good answer.

32.text:
You might think about rainwater, water coming
down from the sky, and that would be a good

37.text:
answer. You might think about mountain streams
up in the the Rocky Mountains, that pristine

42.text:
water coming down from the snow melt. And
you might think about, well what about glaciers

48.text:
and maybe the Arctic ice. And those would
all be good answers.

54.text:
But let me share with you some issues that
might come up with each of those sources of

59.text:
water. While we would think of them as being
the safest water on Earth, each of them can

63.text:
have issues associated with them, and so this
helps us to realize we need to be aware and

69.text:
cautious. Well, let's start with the groundwater.
The groundwater's safer than the surface water

75.text:
because the surface water may have pathogens
in it that may cause the spread of disease,

79.text:
and we talked about London and Chicago in
the 1800s and Milwaukee in 1993. And so we

87.text:
might think, well, the groundwater as the
water flows through the ground, those pathogens

91.text:
die off and that water's safer. And that's
assuming that there's not surface influences

96.text:
on the groundwater that might be introducing
pathogens directly into the groundwater. And

101.text:
that'd be exactly true, but we can think about
naturally occurring arsenic that might be

106.text:
in that groundwater, like in Norman, Oklahoma,
and so we need to think about that groundwater.

112.text:
What about the rainwater? It's not coming
in contact with the geology, so it's not dissolving

116.text:
things out of the geologic materials. Well,
it turns out as that rain falls through the

122.text:
sky, we can get acid rain. And what is acid
rain? Well, you may have nitrogen oxide, you

130.text:
may have sulfur oxides in the atmosphere,
causes combustion and other activities, and

135.text:
as the rain falls through that, it may dissolve
those compounds into the rain, and you may

140.text:
get acid rain. And so that's something we
need to worry about, think about. In the Black

146.text:
Forest in Germany, the trees started dying
because of the acid rain.

151.text:
What about the mountain stream water there,
your snowmelt up in the Rockies? Well, if

156.text:
you talk to a backpacker, people that go backpacking
up in the mountains that have experience,

162.text:
they know not to trust that water. They know
that you need to boil the water, you need

166.text:
to add iodine tablets, you need some special
filter to make that water safe. It turns out

173.text:
the deer and the beavers that are living up
in those mountains, they can excrete Giardia

179.text:
and cryptosporidium into the water, and you
can get deathly ill from that water.

183.text:
Well, what about the Arctic ice, the glaciers?
Well interestingly enough, we find that chlorofluorocarbons,

191.text:
or Freon, and other types of compounds that
have gotten into the atmosphere can move through

196.text:
the atmosphere up to the Arctic ice and partition
in the ice. And so we actually find these

204.text:
And so all of these waters that we think about
as being the safest may actually have water

209.text:
quality issues associated with them. So because
the water quality issues that we may have,

215.text:
we think about treating the water. We treat
water for several different reasons, and we

220.text:
have several different what we call regulations
or standards. We have primary standards, and

226.text:
these standards are focused on human health,
preventing the spread of disease, like cholera,

232.text:
typhoid fever, preventing the exposure to
compounds that may cause cancer, and so these

238.text:
are primary standards to protect the water
that we drink.

242.text:
We also have secondary standards. These secondary
standards aren't designed to protect human

249.text:
health. They're more for aesthetic reasons,
how the water appears. And so maybe the water,

254.text:
for example Lake Thunderbird east of Norman,
if you take a glass of water of Lake Thunderbird

259.text:
water and hold it up, you'll see a lot of
of fine particles. We call that turbidity

265.text:
in the water, and it almost has a little bit
of a reddish color to it. That's because the

269.text:
iron particles in those fine particles give
that color to it. Now those solids in the

276.text:
water may or may not be health issues, but
they're certainly not very pleasing to look

280.text:
at. Iron in the water, you may, if your groundwater
has reducing conditions in the absence of

287.text:
oxygen, you may get iron dissolved in the
water. Now, I remember a time when my wife

292.text:
was on an iron supplement diet, adding more
iron into her diet. At the same time, the

298.text:
city of Memphis was taking iron out of the
drinking water. So that wasn't a health standard.

304.text:
That was because that iron that was in the
water, if it comes into the home and it's

309.text:
in your washing machine and that iron precipitates,
your white shirts or your white tablecloths

313.text:
become pink. And so that's more of an aesthetic
concern, a visual concern. So these are a

319.text:
couple of the reasons that we treat water:
for health concerns, that's the number one--to

324.text:
prevent the spread of disease, to prevent
the episodes of cholera and typhoid fever

329.text:
that we know from our history. But then there
are also things that we do to make the water

335.text:
Well, the type of treatment we consider is
a function of the source of the water. We

340.text:
can have river water can be our source. Our
source could be a lake, like Lake Thunderbird

347.text:
for Norman. Or it could be groundwater, and
Norman historically used groundwater was its

352.text:
source of water, but when Lake Thunderbird
was built in the late 60s, early 70s in that

359.text:
timeframe, that became a source of water.
And so you have different types of treatment

362.text:
processes as a function of what's in the water,
as a function of the source of the water.

368.text:
So let's talk about treating water that's
like a river water or or lake water that has

374.text:
these fine particles, this turbidity in the
water. And one of the first things we want

378.text:
to do is to remove that turbidity, to clear
up that water so that it's more aesthetically

383.text:
pleasing. It turns out these particles are
so fine that they won't settle out very quickly.

388.text:
If you have river water like the Mississippi
River, you have sand that will be in the water

393.text:
because of the the turbulence. The energy
in the water will even be able to suspend

398.text:
sand, and that'll settle, the sand will settle
out very quickly, but these fine clay particles

403.text:
will settle much slower. And so one of the
first steps we do is to take that water and

408.text:
to make those fine particles so that they'll
come together and become larger particles,

413.text:
so that they will settle out by gravity. Now
the process that we use to get these fine

418.text:
particles to come together, we call them to
aggregate or conglomerate, is called coagulation.

425.text:
And coagulation's a process whereby we take
these particles that normally don't want to

429.text:
attach, and we add some chemicals that change
the nature of the surfaces of these particles

434.text:
so that they will attach. And when they come
together, they attach and they become larger

439.text:
and they'll settle out by gravity. And so
that we call that coagulation, and the process

444.text:
of the particles coming together and colliding
and aggregating we call flocculation. Here's

449.text:
a picture from the Draper Water Treatment
Plant in Oklahoma City, and in the left side

456.text:
of the picture what we see is this turbid
water look kind of brownish in nature. And

462.text:
we're doing the coagulation and flocculation.
And as you look to the right part of the figure,

466.text:
you see the water is clear. In the basin we
have these these boards and and they look

472.text:
kind of like a paddle wheel on the back of
a paddlewheel boat, and these paddles rotate

477.text:
very slowly and encourage those particles
to collide and aggregate so they become large

482.text:
enough. And so if you look beyond, you see
the water is clear because the larger particles

486.text:
that we've helped create now settle out of
the water, and the water is much clearer.

492.text:
So the next step after coagulation, flocculation
and settling, gravity settling, is we go into

498.text:
a filter. And here what we mean by a filter
is a sand filter, a bed of sand that the water

504.text:
flows through and helps to further remove
these fine particles that haven't settled

508.text:
out by gravity. Actually this is from Bangkok,
Thailand, and they take water from the Chao

514.text:
Phraya River and then coagulate, flocculate
it and then they put it in the sand filter.

518.text:
You might say, well, where's the sand? What
we're seeing in this picture is the water

523.text:
as its flowing downwards. We can't tell that
it's flowing downwards because it's doing

528.text:
it at a very slow rate, but it's flowing down
through sand that's below the water surface.

533.text:
So looking now at the next picture, we see
what we've done is we've drained the water

537.text:
down in this basin to where now we're seeing
the top of the sand, and we're doing this

543.text:
because we're getting ready to clean the filter.
We've been using this filter long enough it's

547.text:
become very clogged with all the material
that's been removed in the sand. And so in

552.text:
this next picture we see what we've done is
we've begun to flush water back up through

557.text:
the filter in the opposite direction and we're
displacing all this trapped material and we

562.text:
see the color of the water in this case is
kind of brownish, and that reflects the brown

567.text:
particles that were in the surface water that
were trapped by the sand filter. But now we're

572.text:
cleaning that sand filter, removing all that
dirt that had accumulated in it so that we

578.text:
can continue to use the sand filter for additional
treatment of water. So that was the sand filter

584.text:
for Bangkok, Thailand, which was treating
a surface water. Now if we look at the next

590.text:
picture, we see a sand filter, and this is
from Memphis Tennessee. Now we see the color

595.text:
of this water is different. Instead of being
brownish or kind of like a a a chocolate milk

600.text:
or a weak chocolate milk color, we see it's
reddish. And this reflects the fact that in

605.text:
Memphis, it's not the Mississippi River water
that they're treating, it's the groundwater.

610.text:
And they're pumping the water up from the
ground, and that water has iron in it. And

615.text:
so what they're doing is they're precipitating
the iron, and then they're filtering out that

620.text:
iron in their sand filter. So what we're seeing
in this picture is they're running water back

625.text:
through that filter in the opposite direction,
and the iron is becoming displaced from the

630.text:
sand, and now we're regenerating that sand
filter so it can be used to treat additional

637.text:
water. So this would be the steps of coagulation,
flocculation, sedimentation—gravity settling,

644.text:
and now filtration, a sand filter to help
polish or further improve the quality of the

650.text:
But what's the most important reason that
we treat water? It's to prevent the spread

655.text:
of disease--cholera, typhoid fever. And so
the next picture we're looking at, this is

661.text:
a disinfection process, and here what we see
are tanks. And these tanks have chlorine in

668.text:
them, and this chlorine is being added into
the water at just the right concentration

673.text:
to help disinfect that water, to kill any
pathogens that might be in the water. And

678.text:
remember this is the most important reason
we treat the water is to prevent the spread

682.text:
of disease, to prevent the epidemics, from
cholera, typhoid fever. Removing the iron,

690.text:
removing the turbidity, the solids—that
makes the water more pleasant, but treating

695.text:
it with the disinfectant, that makes it safe
and and prevents the spread of disease. So

702.text:
in this example I showed in Memphis, it was
chlorine was the disinfectant. Chlorine gas

708.text:
added into the water to give a residual chlorine
to make the water safe to drink. And you want

714.text:
to make sure that chlorine residual stays
in the water distribution system, so the water

719.text:
coming out of the tap still has that, so the
water can't be re-contaminated by pathogens

724.text:
in the distribution system. This is why I
don't drink the water in a developing country.

728.text:
In Bangkok, I've seen the water treatment
plant. I trust the water at the water treatment

733.text:
plant, but I don't trust it at my hotel because
I'm concerned that it might have been re-contaminated

738.text:
in the distribution system. And so in the
U.S. and Europe, developed countries, we make

743.text:
sure there's a certain residual level of chlorine
or disinfectant at the tap to keep that water

749.text:
safe. We can use other disinfectants, like
ozone or UV light. These can help to disinfect

755.text:
the water, and UV light and ozone are better
for Cryptosporidium and certain pathogens,

759.text:
but they don't leave a residual. They won't
stay in the water all the way to the tap,

764.text:
so even if we use them, we need to add another
chemical to keep that residual disinfectant

And just one more picture. I've shown you
a couple very large water treatment plants.

777.text:
Here's a very small water treatment plant,
and this is from a rural community in central

783.text:
Missouri. We were just driving by and saw
this and stopped and took the picture of it.

787.text:
And this is a system where they're removing
iron, and what you're seeing are a series

792.text:
of trays. They pump this water up, it has
iron in it, and they put it in these trays,

796.text:
and as the water flows from the top down through
these trays, it gets aerated, it gets exposed

802.text:
to oxygen. And the iron precipitates, and
then they're able to remove the iron. And

806.text:
so this is a small plant for a small community
as opposed to the large plants that I've shown

812.text:
Well, having talked about water treatment,
once we use the water in our home, the water

816.text:
goes down the drain, and it goes to the wastewater
treatment plant. And we need to make sure

821.text:
that water is safe before it goes into the
river or lake or the receiving stream, and

825.text:
so next let's talk about wastewater treatment.
So we treat this wastewater to make it safe

830.text:
to discharge into the river or the stream.
And one of the major concerns if that wastewater

835.text:
isn't treated as that waste goes into the
river and stream, it'll consume all the oxygen

840.text:
as the microorganisms consume those organics,
they'll use up the oxygen. And what happens

848.text:
to a river if it doesn't have oxygen in it?
Well, what happens to the fish if there's

854.text:
no oxygen in the fish tank? Well, the fish
die, and so fish and other, many other organisms

861.text:
require oxygen to be able to live in the streams
and lakes. And so what we want to do is we

866.text:
want to get these organics that are in this
wastewater. We want to degrade that, and we

872.text:
want to provide all the oxygen that's necessary
in a treatment plant so when that wastewater

877.text:
goes into the river, it doesn't deplete the
oxygen in the river. And so the way we do

883.text:
that is through a series of processes and
wastewater treatment. So this next picture

888.text:
you're seeing is a picture of the Chao Phraya
River in Bangkok, Thailand. My first trip

894.text:
to Bangkok in 1992 - I wanted to go see a
wastewater treatment plant. The only thing

899.text:
is in 1992, Bangkok had no wastewater treatment
plants. The human waste went into the ditches,

906.text:
into the creeks, and into the Chao Phraya
River untreated. And the dissolved oxygen

911.text:
level in the river was virtually zero, which
meant no fish, no aquatic life could live

917.text:
in that water. I'm happy to report since 1992,
Bangkok has implemented wastewater treatment,

923.text:
and the Chao Phraya River now does support
fish life again, but this is an example of

928.text:
what can happen in the absence. And we in
the United States, we were in that same position

933.text:
in the 1950s and 1960s before we started implementing
the wastewater treatment that we, is so common

941.text:
When we look at a wastewater treatment plant,
what's the first process that we might encounter

946.text:
at the plant? In the first process could be
a filter, a screen to remove large materials

951.text:
that come into the plant, and so that's what
we see in this next picture is just a screen,

957.text:
kind of like a screen door, if you will, a
screen that helps to remove the larger materials

964.text:
from that water. And then we next go into
a process that just allows time for heavy

970.text:
things to settle out. And they say that one
of the things that shows up in this settling

974.text:
basin initially--coffee grounds. Sometimes
people will flush that down the toilet and

980.text:
it makes it to the wastewater treatment plant,
and so that gets settled out. And so we have

983.text:
simple physical processes of screening and
then gravity settling, and that removes those

989.text:
types of materials, but now we're starting
to talk about those dissolved materials. We

994.text:
put some food down our food grinder or down
the garbage disposal that goes down the drain.

1001.text:
We could take those things and put them out
in the compost pile. And we have a compost

1005.text:
pile at our house and so those things would,
those organics would break down in a compost

1009.text:
pile, but sometimes we use our our garbage
disposal, and it goes down the drain. And

1015.text:
if that goes into the river, it'll consume
the oxygen in the river just like it consumes

1019.text:
oxygen in our compost pile as it degrades.
And so now we need to think about: how can

1024.text:
we design processes to help remove those organic
compounds that won't be removed with the screens

1030.text:
or won't be removed by settling? So what we
do to remove these organics is actually somewhat

1036.text:
similar to what we do in a compost pile. If
you've ever worked with a compost pile you

1040.text:
put the organics, you always like to have
compost that's already been composted because

1048.text:
you can put that in, and that brings the microorganisms.
And you need some moisture, you need water.

1054.text:
And you turn your compost pile, and that's
to keep it aerated. So these are some of the

1058.text:
important ingredients when we're thinking
about trying to do biological degradation

1064.text:
And so how do we do this in a wastewater treatment
plant? And I always like it when I got to

1068.text:
a wastewater treatment plant and they have
several basins, and one is in operation but

1073.text:
one's down because they're doing maintenance.
Because you can see what it looks like when

1078.text:
it has water in it, but you can see what it
looks like when it's empty, and that's very

1081.text:
nice in this picture. This is a wastewater
treatment plant from Memphis, Tennessee, and

1084.text:
to the left we see a unit that's in operation.
The wastewater's flowing through it. We see

1090.text:
the basin filled with water. In the center
we see a basin that's dry, and if you notice

1096.text:
down at the bottom of that basin you see a
pipe, and that pipe has little diffusers coming

1103.text:
out of it. It's very similar to what you do
at a fish tank. In a fish tank at the bottom

1107.text:
of the tank you put a little diffuser, and
you pump air in. And that provides the air

1111.text:
that the fish need to stay alive. What we're
doing in this basin is we're bringing the

1116.text:
wastewater, and we're providing air, and we're
also bringing in microorganisms. We're taking

1122.text:
settled sludge and returning it. So we're
bringing all these ingredients together so

1127.text:
that the organics can breakdown in this basin,
in this engineered treatment system rather

1134.text:
than happening in the river itself. So what
happens in this basin is you have microorganisms.

1139.text:
They see food, and they eat that food. To
them—what to us is the wastewater to them

1144.text:
is food. They say, "Pizza!" and get excited
and start eating, and they break down these

1149.text:
organics. And they multiply in a process,
and so we produce lots of microorganisms,

1155.text:
or what we call sludge. We go into the next
basin, which is shown here, and this is the

1160.text:
settling basin. And we allow that sludge,
those microorganisms to settle out to the

1164.text:
bottom, and the water that comes off the top
is devoid of the organics, but also we've

1170.text:
settled out the sludge, the solids, the microorganisms.
And so now we're ready to discharge this water

1176.text:
to the river. You see off in the the horizon
is the Mississippi River, and so now Memphis

1181.text:
has treated this wastewater and it's removed
the solids, it's removed the organics, it's

1186.text:
settled out the microorganisms, and it's ready
to send this water on to the Mississippi River.

1191.text:
And the oxygen level in the Mississippi River
won't be depleted because we've satisfied

1195.text:
that oxygen demand in this engineered treatment
system. So we've protected the receiving body.

1201.text:
We've also protected people downstream that
might pull out Mississippi River water because

1207.text:
we've removed potential pathogens that were
in the water to protect the downstream users.

1215.text:
So we've now talked about treating the wastewater
to remove the solid particles and to remove

1220.text:
the organics, the dissolved organics. Depending
upon the water the wastewater is going into,

1225.text:
if that wastewater's going into a lake, we
may need to remove nitrogen and phosphorus

1230.text:
from the wastewater as well because those
may be limiting factors that are preventing

1236.text:
growth of large amounts of algae, and that
algae can potentially consume oxygen in the

1242.text: water and have a negative impact on the water.

1245.text:
So there's certain situations where we need
to go beyond just simply removing the organics,

1249.text:
and remove the nitrogen and the phosphorus
as well. So we've talk now about water treatment,

1255.text:
wastewater treatment. And in looking at these
processes we've found the combination of physics

1260.text:
(gravity settling), chemistry (adding chemicals
to achieve certain removal processes), microbiology,

1268.text:
we see math, we see public health. And so
hopefully you get a sense of how all these

1273.text:
different disciplines come together to help
us achieve our goal of making our water safe,

1278.text:
our wastewater safe for the environment and
human health.

1281.text:
But just as a final thing, let's think about
what might this look like in a developing

1285.text:
country where people are in a village. A hundred
families in a village living on less than

1291.text:
a dollar per day don't have the resources
to build these sophisticated types of processes

1296.text:
that we're talking about. In those applications
we might be thinking about instead of a wastewater

1301.text:
treatment plant, we might be thinking about
a latrine. But interestingly enough, we maybe

1306.text:
think of a latrine of being at a state park
or a campground, but there's actually some

1311.text:
technology that can go into improving latrines.
And so we talk about ventilated improved pit,

1317.text:
VIP latrines, and we talk about eco-latrines
or composting latrines. And so there's some

1324.text:
technology that can go into making the management
of the wastewater more effective even in these

1330.text:
developing countries. In terms of water treatment,
we can think about simple things. Instead

1334.text:
of a large water treatment plant, we might
be looking at a bottle of chlorine where we

1340.text:
add a capful of the chlorine into a certain
amount of the water. We might be looking at

1346.text:
taking water and putting it in a in a Coke
bottle and putting it on the roof, and the

1352.text:
UV light and the sunlight can disinfect that
water. So we might be looking at very simple.

1357.text:
We might be looking at ceramic water filters
or bile sand filters, so very simple technologies

1363.text:
that use the same concepts but are more appropriate
for that setting.

1368.text:
So in this lesson we talked about the importance
of water treatment, the importance of wastewater

1372.text:
treatment, and some of the different concepts
and processes that we can use trying to make

1377.text:
the water safer for human consumption, more
pleasant for human consumption, safer to discharge

1383.text:
into the environment, safer for people that
might be using the water downstream after

1388.text:
we discharge it into the environment. And
we're hopefully you've seen now the importance

1393.text:
of water treatment and wastewater treatment
to public health and to society as we know
